natural solution: Since we always read the letters clockwise, this is really the same as counting the number of linear permutations of the 5 letters, given that C must go first.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and c :: "(nat \<Rightarrow> char) \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "c = (\<lambda> f. f 1 = CHR ''C'' \<and> f 2 = CHR ''O'' \<and> f 3 = CHR ''U'' \<and> f 4 = CHR ''N'' \<and> f 5 = CHR ''T'')"
and h1 : "n = card {f. c f \<and> (\<forall> i. i \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5} \<longrightarrow> f i \<noteq> f (i mod 5 + 1))}"
shows  "n = 24"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The letters C, O, U, N and T are randomly placed around a circle. One such arrangement is shown here. If we always start with the C and continue to read the rest of the letters in order clockwise, in how many different orders can the letters appear?

[asy]
draw(circle((0,0),1),dashed);
label("U",dir(90));
label("C",dir(90+360/5));
label("O",dir(90+2*360/5));
label("N",dir(90+3*360/5));
label("T",dir(90+4*360/5));
[/asy] The final Answer is 24
 ### Proof
 Since we always read the letters clockwise, this is really the same as counting the number of linear permutations of the 5 letters, given that C must go first.
 So, there are $1 \cdot 4 \cdot 3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1 = 4! = \boxed{24}$ orders.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and c :: "(nat \<Rightarrow> char) \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "c = (\<lambda> f. f 1 = CHR ''C'' \<and> f 2 = CHR ''O'' \<and> f 3 = CHR ''U'' \<and> f 4 = CHR ''N'' \<and> f 5 = CHR ''T'')"
and h1 : "n = card {f. c f \<and> (\<forall> i. i \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5} \<longrightarrow> f i \<noteq> f (i mod 5 + 1))}"
shows  "n = 24"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: How many 5-letter permutations of the word "COUNT" are there such that no two consecutive letters in the permutation are the same as the consecutive letters in the original word "COUNT"? The final answer is 24.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes arrangements :: nat
assumes h0 : "arrangements = fact 4"
shows  "arrangements = 24"
a_1.informal problem: How many different arrangements are possible for 4 distinct items? The final answer is 24.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes count_permutations :: nat
assumes h0 : "count_permutations = factorial 4"
shows  "count_permutations = 24"
a_2.informal problem: Find the number of permutations for a set with 4 distinct elements. The final answer is 24.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and factorial :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "factorial 0 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. factorial (Suc n) = (Suc n) * factorial n"
and h2 : "n = factorial 4"
shows  "n = 24"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The letters C, O, U, N and T are randomly placed around a circle. One such arrangement is shown here. If we always start with the C and continue to read the rest of the letters in order clockwise, in how many different orders can the letters appear?

[asy]
draw(circle((0,0),1),dashed);
label("U",dir(90));
label("C",dir(90+360/5));
label("O",dir(90+2*360/5));
label("N",dir(90+3*360/5));
label("T",dir(90+4*360/5));
[/asy] The final Answer is 24
 ### Proof
 Since we always read the letters clockwise, this is really the same as counting the number of linear permutations of the 5 letters, given that C must go first.
 So, there are $1 \cdot 4 \cdot 3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1 = 4! = \boxed{24}$ orders.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and factorial :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "factorial 0 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. factorial (Suc n) = (Suc n) * factorial n"
and h2 : "n = factorial 4"
shows  "n = 24"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: What is the value of 4 factorial (denoted as $4!$)? The final answer is 24.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes arrangements :: nat
assumes h0 : "C = 1"
and h1 : "O = 2"
and h2 : "U = 3"
and h3 : "N = 4"
and h4 : "T = 5"
and h5 : "arrangements = fact (5 - 1)"
shows  "arrangements = 24"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The letters C, O, U, N and T are randomly placed around a circle. One such arrangement is shown here. If we always start with the C and continue to read the rest of the letters in order clockwise, in how many different orders can the letters appear?

[asy]
draw(circle((0,0),1),dashed);
label("U",dir(90));
label("C",dir(90+360/5));
label("O",dir(90+2*360/5));
label("N",dir(90+3*360/5));
label("T",dir(90+4*360/5));
[/asy] The final Answer is 24
 ### Proof
 Since we always read the letters clockwise, this is really the same as counting the number of linear permutations of the 5 letters, given that C must go first.
 So, there are $1 \cdot 4 \cdot 3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1 = 4! = \boxed{24}$ orders.
 *)

theorem
fixes arrangements :: nat
assumes h0 : "C = 1"
and h1 : "O = 2"
and h2 : "U = 3"
and h3 : "N = 4"
and h4 : "T = 5"
and h5 : "arrangements = fact (5 - 1)"
shows  "arrangements = 24"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: How many different arrangements can be made using the letters C, O, U, N, and T, if each letter can only be used once? The final answer is 24.

fixes C O U N T :: nat
assumes h0 : "distinct [C, O, U, N, T]"
shows  "fact 5 = (24::nat)"
a_5.informal problem: How many distinct permutations can be made from the letters C, O, U, N, and T? The final answer is 24.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 5"
shows  "fact (n - 1) = 24"
a_8.informal problem: What is the factorial of one less than 5? The final answer is 24.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes arrangements :: nat
assumes h0 : "C \<noteq> O"
and h1 : "C \<noteq> U"
and h2 : "C \<noteq> N"
and h3 : "C \<noteq> T"
and h4 : "O \<noteq> U"
and h5 : "O \<noteq> N"
and h6 : "O \<noteq> T"
and h7 : "U \<noteq> N"
and h8 : "U \<noteq> T"
and h9 : "N \<noteq> T"
shows  "arrangements = 24"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The letters C, O, U, N and T are randomly placed around a circle. One such arrangement is shown here. If we always start with the C and continue to read the rest of the letters in order clockwise, in how many different orders can the letters appear?

[asy]
draw(circle((0,0),1),dashed);
label("U",dir(90));
label("C",dir(90+360/5));
label("O",dir(90+2*360/5));
label("N",dir(90+3*360/5));
label("T",dir(90+4*360/5));
[/asy] The final Answer is 24
 ### Proof
 Since we always read the letters clockwise, this is really the same as counting the number of linear permutations of the 5 letters, given that C must go first.
 So, there are $1 \cdot 4 \cdot 3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1 = 4! = \boxed{24}$ orders.
 *)

theorem
fixes arrangements :: nat
assumes h0 : "C \<noteq> O"
and h1 : "C \<noteq> U"
and h2 : "C \<noteq> N"
and h3 : "C \<noteq> T"
and h4 : "O \<noteq> U"
and h5 : "O \<noteq> N"
and h6 : "O \<noteq> T"
and h7 : "U \<noteq> N"
and h8 : "U \<noteq> T"
and h9 : "N \<noteq> T"
shows  "arrangements = 24"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: How many different arrangements can be made using the distinct letters C, O, U, N, and T? The final answer is 24.
